image-wrap.caption: Walker Ridge Area in the Gulf of Mexico

formatted-caption.caption-text: Walker Ridge Area in the Gulf of Mexico

linkTarget.anchoringText: Using the fracture geometry and design, along with reservoir fluid property inputs, fine detail on formation permeability and layering, a proprietary model was developed to study the completion productivity further. Figure 3 shows the Julia #2 log and pre-job fracture modeling. Figure 4 shows a quarter segment of the model with bars showing the permeability distribution and resulting pressure field during production. Despite some higher permeability streaks, simulations showed large consistent drawdowns and production could be acheived across all the pay intervals. In other words, the high permeability streaks did not overpower the lower permeability at ultra-high drawdowns.

image-wrap.label: Figure 3
image-wrap.caption: Julia #2 Well Log with Possible Fracture Spacing and Geometry

formatted-caption.caption-text: Julia #2 Well Log with Possible Fracture Spacing and Geometry

Despite some higher permeability streaks, simulations showed large consistent drawdowns and production could be acheived across all the pay intervals. image-wrap.label: Figure 4
image-wrap.caption: Well Fracture Model Showing Permeability, Flowing Pressure Field and Possible Fracture Geometry

formatted-caption.caption-text: Well Fracture Model Showing Permeability, Flowing Pressure Field and Possible Fracture Geometry

linkTarget.anchoringText: Overall well design was initially based on lessons learned during the drilling of the Julia-1, Julia-2, and similar offset wells (see Figure 5). The Julia Phase I Development drill center is located near Julia-2 well at the edge of the overlying mini-basin where above salt sediments are relatively thick as shown in Figure 6.

Overall well design was initially based on lessons learned during the drilling of the Julia-1, Julia-2, and similar offset wells (see Figure 5). The Julia Phase I Development drill center is located near Julia-2 well at the edge of the overlying mini-basin where above salt sediments are relatively thick as shown in Figure 6.

image-wrap.label: Figure 6
image-wrap.caption: Schematic cross section showing major geologic intervals, a selection of seismically interpreted faults, and Phase 1 well paths

formatted-caption.caption-text: Schematic cross section showing major geologic intervals, a selection of seismically interpreted faults, and Phase 1 well paths

image-wrap.label: Figure 7
image-wrap.caption: Extended Reach vs TVD Depth Plot

formatted-caption.caption-text: Extended Reach vs TVD Depth Plot

linkTarget.anchoringText: A geomechanical model as shown in Figure 8 was built for each well using sonic log data to generate elastic properties. Triaxial, UCS and Brazilian Testing (indirect tensile strength) were performed on sand and shale plugs to calibrate the log-generated dynamic properties with static elastic properties. Preliminary schedules were developed using exploration well logs and offset well data to determine the approximate amount of proppant and gel required for each zone.

image-wrap.label: Figure 8
image-wrap.caption: Lithology and Geomechanical Properties Used in Fracture Design

formatted-caption.caption-text: Lithology and Geomechanical Properties Used in Fracture Design

image-wrap.label: Figure 9
image-wrap.caption: Typical Fracture Pump Schedule (usually ~600-750k# per zone)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Typical Fracture Pump Schedule (usually ~600-750k# per zone)

linkTarget.anchoringText: The fractures for the four completed wells were designed using the methodology described above. Bottomhole pressures are shown in Figure 10 below for a typical 750 klb frac schedule. Bottomhole gauges were run in the bundle carrier as well as along the washpipe. Post-job fracture modeling was performed using the bottomhole gauge data. The initial fracturing pressure and net pressure growth were matched by making adjustments to the geomechanical model and using gel rheology provided from onsite testing. Figure 11 below shows typical washipe data and fracture geometry results for a well with 5 completion zones obtained by matching the bottomhole gauge data.

image-wrap.label: Figure 10
image-wrap.caption: Typical Fracture Treatment Post Job Pressure Plot

formatted-caption.caption-text: Typical Fracture Treatment Post Job Pressure Plot

linkTarget.anchoringText: The fractures for the four completed wells were designed using the methodology described above. Bottomhole pressures are shown in Figure 10 below for a typical 750 klb frac schedule. Bottomhole gauges were run in the bundle carrier as well as along the washpipe. Post-job fracture modeling was performed using the bottomhole gauge data. The initial fracturing pressure and net pressure growth were matched by making adjustments to the geomechanical model and using gel rheology provided from onsite testing. image-wrap.label: Figure 11
image-wrap.caption: Typical Post-Job Estimated Fracture Geometry and Bottomhole Pressure Matching

formatted-caption.caption-text: Typical Post-Job Estimated Fracture Geometry and Bottomhole Pressure Matching

linkTarget.anchoringText: The typical reverse out procedure checked the "U-tube" of pressures on the end of the workstring and in the fracture after shutdown, which also measured and accounted for the frac supercharge pressure and net pressure built in the frac. (Please see Figure 12.) Reverse out pressure was calculated to ensure the backside stayed overbalance to the frac and kept the proppant/gel mixture out of the wellbore fracturing sleeve back to the service tool.

image-wrap.label: Figure 12
image-wrap.caption: Typical Schematic Showing How the Annulus is Kept Overbalanced to the Frac at the End of a Fracture Treatment

formatted-caption.caption-text: Typical Schematic Showing How the Annulus is Kept Overbalanced to the Frac at the End of a Fracture Treatment

image-wrap.label: Figure 13
image-wrap.caption: Typical Values from an Actual Zone Treatment to Calculate Backside Reverse Out Pressure

formatted-caption.caption-text: Typical Values from an Actual Zone Treatment to Calculate Backside Reverse Out Pressure

linkTarget.anchoringText: First oil production at Julia field began in April 2016 with a single producer as shown in Figure 14. The second producer followed in May 2016. With only two producers, early field production peaked at about16,000 bbls/day. Starting in early 2017 production rates were optimized based on surveillance of near wellbore depletion estimates from short build-ups. At this time, one producer's rate was curtailed to mitigate what was deemed to be too large of a near wellbore depletion pressure. In September and November of 2017, the third and fourth wells came online, increasing field production. At present, Julia is producing over 25,000 bbls/day, with a cumulative production of approximately 10 million barrels.

A component of Julia production optimization includes surveillance of near wellbore drawdown (total drawdown) and PTA (pressure transient analysis) derived completion performance (i.e., skin) for all wells. Initial pre-drill estimates of Julia well skins were −2 to −3. To date, actual Julia well skins are nominally−5 at the onset of production (Please see Figure 15). The integrity of each well's skin appears robust with repect to both time on production and total drawdown pressure.

image-wrap.label: Figure 15
image-wrap.caption: Julia completion performace (i.e., skin) vs. time and total drawdown.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Julia completion performace (i.e., skin) vs. time and total drawdown.

linkTarget.anchoringText: To capture all the geomechanical compaction and shear effects that affect the completion, geomechanics based finite element analysis (FEA) was applied to model the reservoir and tubular deformation behavior under well-specific producing conditions. A parametric study of geomechanical loading and tubular resistance was conducted to create a general WOL response surface that can be applied to any well in minutes, and summarizes the current WOL application procedure (Grueschow et al. 2008). The output of the WOL calculation is a graph of drawdown vs. depletion with the corresponding limit state indicated graphically, shown in Figure 16, and thus indicates the limits of drawdown-depletion to avoid well failure.

The two main failure mechanisms were determined to be compaction failure and shear failure. WOLs were calculated for each individual well, taking into account the local rock mechanics of each well path and the specific completion type. The DC101 well was executed as a frac pack completion, with the top zone not being fractured due to an operational decision. (Please see Figure 17.) Note that the shear failure WOL is the limiting factor in this case, governed by the unfractured top zone, and indicates that the well can be safely drawn down to approximately 10,000 psi at 0 psi depletion. Figure 18 shows WOL results for the JU104 well with a successfully executed frac pack in all zones. However, due to the uncertainty of achieving a fully packed annulus, both compaction and shear WOLs were honored.

WOLs were calculated for each individual well, taking into account the local rock mechanics of each well path and the specific completion type. The DC101 well was executed as a frac pack completion, with the top zone not being fractured due to an operational decision. (Please see Figure 17.) Note that the shear failure WOL is the limiting factor in this case, governed by the unfractured top zone, and indicates that the well can be safely drawn down to approximately 10,000 psi at 0 psi depletion. Figure 18 shows WOL results for the JU104 well with a successfully executed frac pack in all zones. However, due to the uncertainty of achieving a fully packed annulus, both compaction and shear WOLs were honored.
